If the overall costs of administering healthcare go up, it may lead to non-drug users making higher contribution payments or losing some guaranteed insurance benefits.
Smoking  tobacco around others means that non-consenting people suffer harm, yet tobacco is legal.
In the UK, there are bans  on smoking in and around enclosed public spaces so as to minimise the harmful effects of smoking on non-smokers.
Secondhand smoke can be particularly harmful for children , who may develop asthma or infections as a result.
People can develop lung problems and even cancer  from secondhand smoke.
Studies indicate that second-hand exposure to freebase cocaine (crack) smoke, by contrast, is unlikely  to have harmful effects.
There is significant support to ban smoking .
Plenty of human actions will have potentially negative impacts on others. It does not follow that states ought to ban those actions.
According to the Harm Principle , the actions of individuals can be curtailed when they infringe upon the rights of others. Insofar as drug use has the potential to harm others, it must be banned.
Driving can have harmful  and potentially fatal consequences for many non-drivers, yet driving is still legal.
Certain forms of low-wage work may damage the health of workers and make it harder  for them to take care of their families. Yet, these are accepted despite the harms they incur to others.
According to Human Rights Watch , subjecting people to disproportionate criminal sanctions for the personal use of drugs "infringes on their autonomy".
Under legalisation, employers worried about lowered productivity may excessively monitor employees to ensure they are not using drugs, which would infringe on the personal freedom of workers.
If we legalise all drugs, people would likely face a greater number of mandatory drug tests  from their employers.
Most employers do not regularly  check their employees for alcohol consumption.
Likewise, bosses may force employees to disclose drug use.

Bosses will likely not waste time and money on routinely monitoring the drug use of all their employees. It is easier and cheaper to reserve tests and surveillance exclusively for cases where they have good reason to suspect an employee is intoxicated while at work.
If drug use is legalised, employees will be able to take legal action if their rights are being infringed upon by drug monitoring.
Since the choice of whether or not to consume drugs is a relatively inconsequential one, it matters very little to citizens' overall personal autonomy if they are denied this choice.

People can already change their mental states with alcohol or even without substances , so the option of legally consuming a greater array of mind-altering drugs would not represent a significant expansion on the current legal activities available.

Free choice is not important just because it allows important decisions to be made autonomously. It is important precisely because only individuals are able to decide what choices are important to them.
Free choice can never be absolute  as one's freedom must always be tempered by the needs of others and the community. As such, relatively unimportant choices are the preferable freedoms to limit.
Governments frequently put restrictions on actions that may cause citizens to harm themselves or others.
Most states ban speech that can cause immediate harms or incite violence  so as to protect other citizens.

Most governments actually do allow their citizens to do a wide variety of potentially dangerous activities, from extreme sports  to drinking alcohol and driving cars, which can lead to death or injury.
The fact that governments do frequently restrict the actions of their citizens does not make this justified.
Many countries ban  or heavily restrict  personal ownership of guns and other weapons.
States are meant to be moral arbiters (p. 710 ) who determine whether certain behaviors are acceptable or not. Given the dangers of drugs, states must declare them unacceptable.
Democratic  states are meant to aggregate and represent the views of their citizens. Thus, if the public favours legalisation of drugs, the laws their state enshrines should reflect that preference.
Support for legalising stronger drugs than marijuana is actually quite low, even in the US .
In places like Oregon , where general drug decriminalisation has been put to a vote, it has often won, indicating that people are happy to decriminalise more drugs than just marijuana.
In many parts of Asia , where there exist strict anti-drug laws, there is little support for decriminalisation or legalisation of any sort.
In many countries, large numbers of voters support the legalisation of marijuana, particularly in the US  and UK .
Even if many people support drug use and legalisation, insofar as it is so potentially dangerous, states are justified in usurping that democratic will to protect the interests of their citizens.
According to utilitarian accounts , the primary purpose of a state is to prevent harm coming to its citizens. As such, it is a state's purpose to determine what actions cause harm and stop them.
State power is always potentially corrosive to the rights of individuals. Therefore, governments should, in most cases, allow citizens to determine their own best interests for themselves (2.1 ).

This rule would allow an unreasonably small number of cases where states are allowed to intervene in the affairs of citizens. Most people accept that states can adopt moral stances and prevent certain dangerous actions.
State intervention is often justified in cases where individuals do not use reason effectively . Insofar as individuals consume drugs despite the harms, drug policy can be considered such an area.
While this does suggest that states would be justified in adopting a moralising, anti-drug stance and producing corresponding propaganda, it does not follow that they should ban drugs altogether.
Criminalisation has not protected citizens from drugs.

While the War on Drugs has failed, there exist other proposals for 'smart'  drug prohibition which may work better. As such, the historical record is insufficient to declare that criminalisation has failed.
According to the Global Commission on Drug Policy , the War on Drugs has been a failure.
